original_title: Sri Lanka rupee gains to close at Rs353.46/353.50 to US dollar
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka rupee closed at 353.46/353.50 to the US dollar in the spot market Wednesday hitting the strong end of a guidance peg, dealers said as negative private credit reduced outflows.
The rupee opened at 353/355 to the US dollar as the central bank set a 358.46 rupees to the dollar guidance peg in the morning with banks allowed to trade up to 5 rupees on either side.
The central bank has been buying dollars steadily over week, market participants said.
As the rupee appreciates and the central bank buys dollars filling liquidity shortages in the banking system, interest rates tend to fall.
A bond maturing on 01.02.2025 closed at 32.00/15 percent on Wednesday, down from 32.10/25 percent on Tuesday.
A bond maturing on 15.05.2026 closed at 29.20/60 percent, down from yesterday’s close at 29.50/70 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.09.2027 closed at 28.80/90, down from yesterday’s close at 29.10/30 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.001.2028 closed at 27.00/30, Down from yesterday’s close at 28.00/30 percent.
A pegged exchange rate central bank is able to buy dollars (deploying a so-called strong side convertibility undertaking), when domestic credit is weak, indicating that interest rates should fall.
Sri Lanka’s interest rates are elevated due to fears of domestic debt re-structuring.
Due to a flaw in the International Monetary Fund driven debt workouts, no cut-off date is announced for domestic debt re-structuring, reducing demand especially from banks for the Treasuries.
Sri Lanka’s rupee collapsed from 200 to 360 to the US dollar after two years of money printed for output gap targeting, an action which was probably illegal under existing monetary law.
However, in a draft monetary law, output gap targeting appears to be have been legalized.
Countries with monetary instability cannot grow steadily, and have weak growth prospects, making it difficult to expand GDP and reduce debt.
